texts.shortText:
The only species in this genus and family and the largest of all living turtles. Unmistakable due to the lack of a bony shell.

Carapace broad and streamlined, covered with a flexible, leathery skin bearing 7 very prominent longitudinal ridges that meet posteriorly. Head massive and cannot be fully withdrawn into the shell. Beak bicuspid. Front flippers massive and may have a span exceeding 3 m, hind limbs much smaller, strongly webbed and paddle-like, all limbs clawless. Colour dark-gray to black, blotched with white, underside paler.
Total length normally up to 180 cm (can reach 250 cm) and mass of up to 500 kg (can reach 860 kg).

Global: Distributed world-wide in tropical and temperate seas, but many sub-populations have been severely depleted, both due to direct exploitation and as a result of accidental by-catch by commercial long-line and gill-net fisheries.

Local/Regional: Nest in KwaZulu-Natal and Mozambique and most often encountered there, but have been reported throughout the region.

Cosmopolitan and fast-swimming, some tagged individuals covering thousands of kilometers per year. Males spend their entire lives at sea and females only come ashore to lay their eggs.

Well known for their ability to maintain body temperature up to 18°C above ambient water temperature, which allows them to range into cooler, temperate waters. This is achieved by ability to conserve metabolic body heat as a result of their large body size, small surface to volume ratio, layers of insulating fat and an efficient counter current exchange system in the flippers.

The most accomplished of reptilian divers, spending about 60 % of their time at depths of 10–250 m and diving for over 40 minutes on a single breath. Deepest recorded dives to over 1200 m.

Feeds almost entirely on jellyfish and other soft-bodied organisms such as siphonophores, tunicates and cephalopods. May ingest plastic bags and similar marine debris, mistaking these for food items, and these may obstruct the digestive tract and cause death.

Sexual maturity is achieved at an ago of 5–14 years. Mating takes place at sea and females return to the same beach where they were born to nest, in October to January in South Africa. Females drag themselves up the beach at night and excavate holes above the high-water mark using their hind flippers. Clutches of about 100 eggs are laid and the hole then filled in. The same female then returns to lay another batch of eggs at about 10-day intervals, laying up to 1000 eggs in a season. Eggs hatch after about 60–70 days and at a size of about 6 cm and 45 g. As in all turtles, the sex ratio of offspring is determined by incubation temperature, eggs incubated at temperatures above about 29.4°C developing mostly into females and those below this temperature into males. Newly hatched young emerge mainly at night to avoid predation, and may be heavily predated by crabs, seabirds and fish especially if they emerge by day.
Unmistakable due their enormous size and lack of shell plates.

Alexander, G & Marais, J (2007). A Guide to the Reptiles of Southern Africa, Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 368).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 344).
